body.div:
Ch V– 113
He
then put the following letter
into my hands.
"To V. Frankenstien
Geneva Apri l March 18 17—
"My
dear
Cousin
"I cannot describe to you the uneasi
ness we have all felt concerning your
health. We cannot help imagining that
your friend Clerval conceals the ex
tent of your
disorder,
for it is now
several months since we have seen
your
handwriting
and all this time
you have been obliged to dictate
to
Henry – Surely Victor
you must have
been
very ill
and this makes us
and this makes us
mother
My
father
was
almost
persuaded
of this that you were indeed dangerously ill,
of this that you were indeed dangerously ill,
and
could hardly
be be
re f st rain ed
from
߶
undertaking
undertaking
a journey to Ingolstadt.
I but I entreated him not
to undertake it
because
^
for
although his health is better now
tha t n it has been since the death
of My beloved Aunt, yet tha the fatigue
might have
make him very ill and
Clerval
always
wr o i te s
that
you
were
getting
better and
^
I
and
^
I
I
arden eagerly
hope you
will confirm this intelligence soon in your own
handwriting
for indeed,
indeed Victor
we are all very
uneasy
^
miserable on this
account
Relieve
us from this
fear
and we shall
be the happiest creatures in the
world.–
My uncles
health
impro is
now
well &
far
vigorous
that he appears
ten years younger since last
winter. Ernest also is so much
im
proved, so
that
you would
hardly
know
him;
he is now nearly
sixteen
you know
and has
quite lost that
sickly appearance
that
he had
some years
ago –
he is
quite
well
&
hearty
if I y may use that term for it is
very expressive.
"My uncle and I conversed
the
last night a long time
about what
profession profession
should be
should
should be
should
follow
His constant
ill health
when young has deprived
him of
the
habit
of
application
and now
that
he
enjoys good
health we
he
is continually
in the open
air on
climbing the
hills
or rowing on the
lake.
I, therefore,
proposed that
he should be be
farmer
which you
know cousin
is a favourite scheme
of
mine –A farmer's
is a very healthy
& happy life; and the least
hurtful
or rather the most
benificial of any
profession.
^
^
of any.
father uncle had an
idea of his being
^
educated as
& that
& that
interrest
he might become he might become
But
besides that
he is not at all
fit
for such an
occupation, it is certainly
better more
better more
honourable creditable
to cultivate the earth for the suste
nance of
man
than
it to be the
confid
a nt
& sometimes
a helpmate the
a helpmate the
accomplice
of
their his
their his
employment
^
&
of
a Lawyer.
And if he should become
a judge I
said
that
a rich the
a rich the
if
it
were not a more
honourable
it was
at least a happier
employ
ment
than that of a judge, whose
misfortune it was always to meddle
with the dark side of human
nature
My uncle
smiled
and
said
that I
ou g t ought to be an advocate
myself;
which put an end to the conversation
on that
subject
And
now I must tell you a little
story that will
please
you. Do you
not remember
Ju Justine
Martin ?
Moritz?
Perhaps
you do
not
I will
therefore
tell you
her
story
in a few words.
Mad.
Martin
her
Mother
was a widow with
four
children
of whom
this Justine
was the third. This girl had always been
the
favou favourite of her
father
and
but by thro an odd perversity
her Mother
never could
bear
^
not endure
after the
death of M.
Martin Moritz
treated her very ill.
My aunt observed
this, and
when Justine
was
ten twelve years
old too
prevailed
on her mother to allow her to live
at
our
house.
X
X
The republican
institutions of our
X
X
The republican
institutions of our
state country,
have
produced simpler
& happier manners
than those which
prevail in the
great monarchies
that surround it.
Ju Whilst
Hence there
is less
dis tinction s
between the classes
into which human beings have been divided,
& the lower orders being neither so poor nor so
despised
are more refined & moral. A servant
at
Geneva does not mean the same thing as a servant in France
or England —Justine was
thus
recieved into
our
family to learn
the duties of a
servant, which
in our fortunate
country
does not include a
sacrifize
of the
dignity
of a human being.
I dare say
that you
now
remember
all about it,
for Justine
was a great favourite of
yours,
& I
remember recollect
remember recollect
you once
said,
that
if you were
a in an
ill
humour
one glance from
Justine,
could dissi
pate
it from
from
for the same reason
that Ariosto
gave
concerning the
beauty of
Angelica:– she
looked so
frank hearted
and happy. My Aunt
was very fond of her which caused concieved an concieved an
attachment for her, by which she
^
was
induced
her to
^
to
to
give her an
d education
superior to that which she
^
had
had
at
first
intended . and she
. and she was fully
repaid;
for Justine was the most
grateful little creature in the
world.
I do not mean that she
made any
professions–I
never
heard one pass her
lips w
but
you could see by her
eye
that
she almost adored her protectress.
Although
very
gay, and in many respects
inconsiderate, yet she paid
the greatest
attention to every gesture of my
Aunt–
she thought her the
miracle model
miracle model
of all
excellence,
and endeavoured to imi
tate her
words
and
even her man
ners,
so that
^
even
even
now she
very often
puts
reminds
me
in mind of her.
You did not observe
all this, nor did I at the time but
it struck me afterwards when I
reflected on the subject.
When
my dearest Aunt
died
every
one was too much occupied in their
own
grif grief to notice poor
Justine
who had attended her during her
whole
illness with the
greatest
affection.
Poor Justine was very
ill
but other
tryals
were reserved for her.
One
by
one
her brothers & sister
had died
and her
mother was now
with the exception of her neglected
daugher was
left childless. The
conscience of the woman was
troubled
and
she began to think that the
deaths of her favourites was a
judgement
sent sent from heaven to
punish chastise
punish chastise
her
partialli n t y
she was a roman
Catholic
and I believe
her confessor
encouraged
the idea
^
which she had
concieved.
a few Months after your depar
ture for
i I ngolstadt, sh
Justine was called
home by her repentant Mother. Poor
girl
she wept when she quitted our
house
she was much altered since the death
of my
aunt:
grief had given
soft e n ess
and a winning mildness to her
manners
which had before been remarkable
for vivacity. Nor
did was her residence
at her
Mothers
house of a nature to
restore her gaiety. The poor
fo wo
man
was very vacillating in her
repentance. She sometimes begged
Justine to forgive her
unkindness
but much
oftenor
accused her
as
having caused the deaths of
h her
brothers & sister. Perpetual fretting
at
last
threw
Mad. Martin
into
a decline, which at first
encreased
her irritability, but she is now at
rest
for
ever; for
S
she
did died
on the first approach of cold
at
the beginning of
th e is
^ last
Justine has
returned to
us
and I assure you
I love her tenderly. She is very clever
and
extremely mild
&
pretty and
as
I mentioned
before she is
her
air mein
and
her expressions
are continually remind me
of my dear Aunt.
And I
must say a few words to
you also,
My dear
Victor,
of little darling
William. I wish you could see
him.
He
is very tall of his
age
with sweet laughing
blue
eyes and
dark
eyelashes
and curling
hair
When he
smiles
two little dimples
appear on
his cheeks
which are rosy
with
health — his chin comes down in
a beautiful oval a After this descrip
tion I can only say what our visitors
say a thousand times a day–'He is too
pretty for a boy'.
X
X
old to
Miss Mansfeld Now,
dear
Victor
I dare
say
I you wish to be indulged in a little
gossip
about your acquaintance.
The
pretty Miss
Mansfeld
has already received
on her the congratulatory visits on her
approaching marriage with a young
Englishman, John
Mebourne Mel
bourne
Esq. Her ugly
sister Manon
married M.
Hofland
the rich
banker
last
autumn. Your favourite
schoolfellow
Louis
Manoir ma
has suffered several
misfortunes
d since the departure
of Clerval from
Geneva b
But he
has
atready already recovered his
spirits
and
he
reported to
m be on the point
of marrying a very lively pretty
french
woman— Mad. Tavernier –She
is a
widow
and much older than
Manoir
but
she is much
adv admired
and a
favourite with
every body.
I
have written myself into
good
spi
rits,
dear
Cousin
yet I
can not
conclude
without again anxiously
enquiring
concerning your
health—
Dear Victor, if
you are not very
ill
write
yourself
and make your father and all
of us
happy or— I
cannot bear to
think
of
^
on
the
other side
of the
question
my tears al
ready
flow
Your very affectionate Cousin
dearrest – dearest Victor ) Elizabeth Lavenza
write–
